item.title: Make It Work: How to Get Honest Feedback?
item.description: The last thing you want is an employee who, in a final twist of irony, provides their only honest feedback during the exit interview.  Have a question about work you want to ask Shane? The number of managers who view feedback as a one-way street would make NYC’s grid blush. Do you have any advice for soliciting honest feedback? I had a manager who would ask during every 1-1 session if I had any feedback for them, a tactic I later found myself using with a few of my direct reports. The honest feedback comes to me and then I address it here on Sunday—what gives?  I’ve found the best strategy for collecting feedback from employees to be a diversified one. Write in here. Ask Shane here. Be one of the first subscribers to our upcoming newsletter on all things human resources.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Allbirds Becomes Latest DTC Startup to Make a Run at the Public Markets
item.description: Zoom out: Allbirds and Warby Parker are just a couple wildebeests in a bigger stampede of consumer-facing companies headed to the public markets.  Both Allbirds and Warby Parker successfully leveraged online channels to attract urban millennials comfortable with buying apparel on the internet. Warby is also ditching the classic IPO playbook by going public via direct listing, which means it’s not actually going to raise any money in the process.  Sounds familiarIn that way, and in many others, it’s similar to Warby Parker, the e-commerce eyewear seller that filed to go public last week.

item.title: What You Need to Know About Elizabeth Holmes’s Trial That Starts Today
item.description: Here’s a quick timeline for everyone who was too young or busy in the aughts: 2003: At the age of 19, Elizabeth Holmes dropped out of Stanford and started Theranos with the goal of revolutionizing blood testing. Jury selection begins today for the criminal fraud trial of Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of shuttered Silicon Valley biotech startup Theranos. Holmes’s net worth also grew to $4.5 billion, good enough for No. 1 on the Forbes list of America’s Richest Self-Made Women. From there, investors started suing for fraud, the government yanked the company’s blood-testing license, and in September 2018, the SEC dissolved Theranos. — MM
